The point you raise is really one which has caused us quite a considerable amount of difficulty in the past, and I think it should be tackled now in the right manner in order to get the matter settled satisfactorily in the future. Nearly all the Customs AdministKations charge duty on c. i. f value of the goods imported. This has caused a certain amount of annoyance to consignees in the case of freight, as owing to the high rates paid for sir freightage, the c. i. f value of goods sent by air is increased enormously and it is necessary some-times to pay duty on more than double the value of the goods themselves. Very often, in fact, in the case of cheap goods wni ch are urgently needed and are therefore sent by air, the majority of the duty paid has been on the actual freightage on the goods, the declared value itself being a very small proportion. Most Customs Administsations have admitted that this state of affairs is quite definitely unlair, as i t penalises goods sent by air and subtsacts to a great extent from the value of ourservices for freight. I think it might be suggested to the Director of Customs at Bahrein that he should adopt the same procedure. Actually, of course, with regard to stores, we do not pay freightage on these goods ourselves as they are carried free on our own services. Further, all stores in transit are covered by a floating policy and we do not pay ordinary insurance rates. I should be glad if you would do your best to persuade the Director of Customs that as we do not pay any freight rates or insurance on our own stores, we should only be charged duty on the declared value of the goods, as this is really equal to the c. i. f value. physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end. The file notes at the end of the file (ff 33-35) should mirror the chronological arrangement, but have been incorrectly arranged. To follow the correct chronological sequence, the notes should be read in the following order: 34, 35, 33.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover and terminates at the back cover; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present between ff 3-32; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: The file’s contents relate to a request from Imperial Airways Limited for a change in the level of customs duty payable on goods brought into Bahrain by their aircraft, which, they argue, is unreasonably high. The principal correspondents in the file are unnamed representatives of Imperial Airways Limited, the Bahrain Political Agent, Lieutenant-Colonel Percy Gordon Loch, and the Political Resident, Lieutenant-Colonel Trenchard William Craven Fowle.The first part of the file is chiefly comprised of correspondence from Imperial Airways Limited (ff 3-10), who raise an objection to the high rates of duty paid on air freight at Bahrain, and recommending an adjusted duty based on the declared value of the goods plus a third of the air freightage. The second part of the file comprises discussion between the Bahrain Political Agent and Political Resident, in concert with officials from the India Office and Air Ministry, on the Imperial Airways request. Reference is made to the ruler of Bahrain, Sheikh Ḥamad bin ‘Īsá Āl Khalīfah’s assent to the change (f 31). The file includes a copy of an official notice from the Customs House in Bahrain, dated 14 July 1934, announcing the agreed changes to the air freight customs duty at Bahrain (f 29).
